Example: Upon clicking like on your "How much does a shadow weigh" video, youtube took it upon itself to recommend cat videos along with nonsensical mumble rap videos. NEITHER of which have anything at all to do with your posted video.
Deselected the like and those recommendations died down.

If I click your video link, it means you have earned the click in some fashion. That means I like it on some level.
But until youtube actually learns how to recommend videos, clicking like is not an option for me.

I have an old video from a music festival in Austin TX where there was some outdoor restaurants. Music was playing over a loud speaker but there was no band playing, it was just a recording. Everyone knew that because it was an old Janis Joplin song so there was no applause from anyone when the song ended. A little girl and 3 to 4 years old, who wasn't even the focus of the camera, didn't realize the music wasn't live or just hadn't yet understood when to applaud. Well the song ended and she clapped just a few times before quickly stopping and looking around at everyone. Her shoulders slumped and her hands dropped almost disappointed. It was a priceless little kid moment and a real learning moment for her. It's actually my favorite part of that days recording.

Why do European audiences tend to clap in sync? I think tapping the floor with a staff or cane was by far the best method of signaling approval. The relatively modern concept of the "slow clap" was devised as a way to usher in the era of group-think. If one person in the group stands while clapping, the hive mind will do do likewise; surely it would be rude to remain seated.

Also: Why do some people clap at the end of a film? That is very awkward and is akin to a tree falling in the forest with no one to hear it. I'm sure Tom Hanks appreciated the woman that stood up to applaud the 4:15 showing of Forrest Gump at AMC Oakview Plaza 24 in Omaha NE - back in the day.

I think we clap, as a form of drawing attention. Like saying hey check this out, how good is this thing I'm watching. When we appreciate something and want others to join in on that experience we call out.  Before we had methods of elevating noise ie microphones and tv etc.., we had to draw attention by noise so that others heard us and joined in. Using your voice can lead to bias by the listener who might dismiss your loud vocal appreciation but if you clap or stomp your feet then we can't infer anything but are forced to go towards the sound.
Likes are also documentation of approval, where as applause is finite.

I wonder if any Netflix CEO has watched this video. Netflix recently replaced its 5 star rating system by a like/dislike rating system. I read that Netflix needed a better way of capturing how much their subscribers actually enjoyed a movie themselves, not just how objectively good they think the movie was.

Apparently, people subconsciously try to be critics when they rate a movie or show from one to five stars, which means Netflix can't use these ratings to customize content and personalize offers effectively. So, as counterintuitive as it sounds, less sophisticated, less detailed rating systems reveal more about individual preferences than 'nuanced' ratings, at least that's what Netflix want's us to believe (which, by the way, doesn't necessarily mean it isn't true).

Obviously, Netflix' success is entirely based on 'consumer cocooning' and private 'informal consumption', so unless you like watching movies with friends and family, I guess you can stop applauding at the end of movies; it's as useless as the applause at your funeral.

I think the reason why clapping has become popular as a way of expressing approval and enthusiasm for a performance is because it doesn't interfere with itself and doesn't carry any secondary messages, and also doesn't hurt as much to do to excess. If people chant, they need to carefully focus on staying in tune while simultaneously keeping up the volume, and if a moderate amount of background noise is present or the message isn't coordinated the words become garbled. Clapping on the other hand just becomes louder the more people do it and the more enthusiasm they do it with, no matter how uncoordinated the group is. Similarly, if 10,000 people like a video, it is clearly being shown more approval than a smaller number, even if none of the individual likers coordinate in any way. More likes is just a louder clap, and to extend the analogy further comments can be viewed like the excited hoots and fanmade signs (and occasional boos), distinct from the clapping but still adding to the applause. Of course, comments are even better because they can actually share ideas on the subject, and because of the separating power of computers the individual voices can be heard separately and understood rather than being muddled or lost in the noise.
Proto-iWatch at 8:29

My first guess was that it was related to the origins of the practice of knocking on wood or just generally making noise to ward off evil spirits. In many Western cultures, when you speak about fortune, you knock on wood, hoping that the noise wards off the demons aiming to curse or jinx you. The practice of fireworks at New Year's Eve comes from the same general idea, hoping that you start the new year with good luck.
Where this connects back to showing appreciation is that when somebody achieves a difficult task, that speaks of rather good fortune. And since good fortune can't last, there must be bad fortune right around the corner. If you want to prevent that, you'll just have to make some noise. It is both an expression of your appreciation for their task or performance and a wish of good luck in future endeavors.
Interestingly, in many circumstances, clapping is replaced by literally knocking on wood. In university (in Germany, at least), when the lecture, presentation or seminar is over, you don't clap. No, you repeatedly knock on your table. It has the same point as applause after a performance: Showing appreciation to the speaker while blending into a crowd. And to me, that seems remarkably similar to the practice of knocking on wood to ward off bad fortune.

Of course, this is all just guesswork. The idea of applause to show appreciation goes back a long, long way. I have no clue whether the idea of "noise -> good fortune" has similarly old and reputable sources. Still, it was a nice exercise.

Some stuff is flagged "liked" by 20 individuals. A next person shares her/his admiration to this stuff. But the one wants not to be alone, to just clap lonely and leave. In this purpose she/he displays the other 20 people who have left their "like-signs" before. The list might look like this: Smith, Jones, Brown, Johnson, Thompson, Jackson and so on. Do our protagonist know any person from the list? Probably doesn't. What she/he knows about these characters? Barely nothing. First, Micheal,
I have to thank you for the chart of hand positions and their respective spectral analysis charts. Even after my education as an audio recording and mixing engineer, I'm still finding creative ideas and tips like this that continue to surprise, and motivate me.

This being said, I strongly disagree with your statements saying that the harmonics of a clap are what make it 'unusable' as a melodic instrument (an instrument with a tonal center). For example, a square wave is the result of one frequency, being multiplied my odd numbers, and then being stacked on top of each other. This is called additive synthases, and in my experience, is the most commonly practiced forms of synthases.

What makes most claps unusable is the fact that most lack a fundamental frequency, or a prominent harmonic frequency(a specific point in the sound where the harmonics are louder, therefor show up as a peak in the chart). Even in the chart it shows that A1+, A1, and A-1 ALL have a tonal center between 0 kHz and 1 kHz. In fact, these kinds of claps are commonly used in almost every genre of music. As you can see in the other examples who don't have a fundamental frequency still possess these frequencies, they are just at the same amplitude as the rest.

Sincerely,
Chris S.

I remember when I used to watch Tough Crowd on comedy central, the main host, Colin Quinn used to yell at the audience to "DON'T CLAP, IT USES TOO MUCH TIME". Because whenever a comic would make a point that the audience agreed with, they couldn't talk because they would have to wait for the audience to shut up.

On some sitcoms filmed in front of live studio audiences, characters would sometimes unnaturally pause or break in their dialog because the audience would cheer or clap. The best example of this was on Married With Children when Christina Applegate would walk on the set.

Very interesting video, while listening i also just thought about my own experiences like just a few minutes ago watching live UFC on my TV, Big Foot Vs Hunt, I'm from the UK so had to stay up till gone 5am in the morning so it's not a very 'sociable' experience often and UFC isn't that big here in the UK, so i was watching it alone, HOWEVER at the end of the fight that lasted the full 25 minutes it was truly a great fight, even during the last 5 minutes of the fight, i was on my feet (excitement) during the 5 minutes that followed i punched the air, i made comments out loud, and of course.. i applauded, the video made me think why i did those things, i was alone nobody knew what i did or care so why did i bother? it was just a human response to what i was seeing, i was standing because i was excited, i punched the air as an admiration gesture, i clapped to show respect even if it meant so little and i made comments to aid this.

We can move faster than the speed of light relative to another position, however. If we somehow manage to warp space. If we develop a technology that dramatically compresses space in front of an object while simultaneously expanding it behind, an object can travel faster than light relative to space outside but riding inside a compression wave inside of which an object would not have to break the light barrier.

Objects cannot travel faster than the speed of light, so imagining what would happen if they did gets silly.

You're hand gains mass as it speeds up, and at light speed, your hand would become infinitely massive and become a black hole.  Time also slows down as you gain speed.  At light speed, time stops.  Further, your hand would also have infinite energy, which would explode the universe.  So would it hit your target? No.

This is why they say traveling light speed is impossible.

We can't imagine new colours because colours are the labels given to particular points on the light spectrum. If human eyes could detect wavelengths beyond visible light and see UV and IR it would be experienced as new colours. The simple answer as to why there are no new colours is that there aren't any, it's like trying to imagine a new number between 1 and 10 - you can only have integers (like 4) and numbers between integers (like 5.76754). Because it's impossible. Colors are light emitting from something (a surface, a cloud of hydrogen etc) and light has frequency of about 380µm (purple) to 760µm (red). Every possible color is between those frequencies and thus a color other than some of those can't be imagined because it doesn't exist.
Unrelated note: Black and white aren't actually colors, because black sucks all the light in itself and white reflects all of it away, and hence they don't have a solid frequency that colors have.

When you speak, the sound of your voice spreads throughout the room, as well as resonate throughout your sinus cavities. You hear the sound of your voice spreading throughout the room being blended with the sound it makes in your sinus cavities. Other people (and cameras) will only hear the sound that spreads through the room. This is why you hear your voice differently than others do.
cause you hear the sounds that are coming out of your mouth  AND the vibration trough your body that travels to your ear
Why can't humans grow wings and fly?

Because your voice is created through the vibration of your vocal chords. For other people, their ears pick up these vibrations and then register them. Recording equipment also picks up these vibrations and takes them down. But you pick up two sets of vibrations, in a way. First, your ears pick up the external sound waves that you have created and register them. But you also feel and "hear" those vibrations through your head. Since you pick up two types of vibrations you hear a different sound.
Because wet get lonely?

When you speak, vibrations from your vocal cords resonate in your throat and mouth, and some get transmitted and conducted by the bones in your neck and head. The inner ear responds to these just like any other vibrations, turning them into electrical signals and sending them to the brain. Whenever you speak, your inner ear is stimulated both by internal vibrations in your bones and by the sound coming out of your mouth and traveling through the air and into the ears

2/2 So what we have to interpret data is ultimately our senses. The way we know that's correct is by common observances. Think about numbers. How do we know four is really four? Well, we count. But who's to say we didn't miscount? Whoever else is counting. But since we're operating from a collection of observances that have been so universally established that they're accepted as fact, we know four is four because so many people have told us it is. We work off that data to make conclusions.

1/2 This is actually fairly easy. We know by forming frames of reference. For example, if you see a duck crossing the street, I see a duck crossing the street, another guy sees a duck, etc. you know a duck is crossing the street. We don't just have ourselves to work off of. We have others. We observe phenomena and if a sufficient number of qualified individuals interpret them in the same way, we have consensus. I say the sky is blue. You say the sky is blue. Everyone else says the sky is blue.

An example would be novel studies. I really enjoy reading, however books that are introduced in school are often thought to be boring because it was introduced in school. We won't appreciate it as much, only because it has been forced upon us. As a summary[TL;DR], anything we are forced to learn becomes a chore; anything we interpret as a chore becomes boring, this is why learning in school is boring. Learning on youtube is done by choice and our own curiosity.

As suck youtube videos that we view on our own time have actually two leading factors that make us more drawn towards learning. First many of the people who create these videos mostly create videos on curiosities that we may not have thought about, but as stated before now we are curios of knowing more about a curious topic. Also, school in general is seen as boring, so any topics introduced in schools are usually labelled as boring, even if they may not be.

Human nature loves learning. So the first thought is that school should fundamentally be fun, however most people do not find it fun. One of the best explanations is that while learning is something humans are drawn towards, if it is about topics that we are not interested in or do not concern us we have a tendency to turn a blind side towards that kind of knowledge. Thus our brains do not interpret such learning as fun. Things that spark interest and curiosity is what we best interpret as fun.

What is never addressed in this video is the fact that clapping as a show of approval or appreciation is culturally specific to the West.  As Western culture spreads and increases its influence, Western practices such as clapping are becoming more commonplace.  Even so, other cultures see applause as an alien practice.  Not only do audiences show their appreciation or approval in many different ways, clapping itself often has entirely different connotations from what Westerners are used to.

That said the rating in the end should really just vote "like" or "dislike" , the rating between 0-10 is good if its actual true, uninfluenced and a workaround for the problematic of "haters" and "fanboys" , which it really isnt.

And if you take a higher number, say 0-100 it really doesnt get better, as nearly all games will go around 80, unless they are uterly horrible, so a rating "like/dislike" would give you the same result

It might seem so, but the rating method comes down to like/dislike

but average isnt good aswell, especially if its visible before voting ; as then, you will have a bunch of people rate exactly the average, as it influences them (which votes try to avoid mostly).

Also average means you have a ton of ratings that are still 10 or 0, as haters will give a crazy low rating and fanboys rate it high, your "average" isnt really helping you, as its so dependent on the number of haters/fanboys alone (so you will have such games rated 7, which is still silly).

This is called the "Forgetting Curve" The human brain usually will try and remember all kinds of things, however sometimes it forgets a lot of minor things. If you learn something new, and you're studying it. Over a course of at least a week you forget about 80% of what you have just learned. However, you can reduce this amount to only 50% if you just review your information. The Forgetting curve is there to get rid of useless memories and make room for other more important matters.

as with most common human behaviours it is most likely a result of evolution. Perhaps those that seek long term mates were more likely to successfully breed and raise offspring. And so with time the seeking of relationships become a common characteristic of humans. Perhaps having a monogamous relationship meant that the female had more support while nurturing the baby and hence was more successful at passing on both hers and the fathers genes.

But that's the simple answer... Relationships aren't something that is exclusive to just humans seeking their own happiness. In fact they exist throughout the entire animal kingdom. Relationships came about due to the fact that you (or most other living beings) cannot do much by themselves: a lion can't mate with itself, a baby can't raise itself, and even you wouldn't be here if you were by... yourself. Relationships at their core are simply a means of survival.

comment_text:
There's a difference b/t the colloquial and scientific definitions of 'theory,' which is, I think, your stumbling block. 

In common usage, a theory is simply any idea that holds some merit, synonymous with guess, hypothesis, or hunch.

In the sciences, however, a theory is as close to fact as we can get, a hypothesis that we can't seem to disprove. Evolution may simply be a 'theory,' but to argue against it would be as ridiculous as arguing that the sun rises in the ~west instead of the ~east.

I don't see what that has to do with why organisms die.

Also, the theory of evolution doesn't suggest that every new generation has a better chance of survival than the last. It only says that every new generation is slightly different. When that difference is more advantageous to the organism's survival and ability to reproduce, then it can pass those changes on to it's offspring. When the changes hinder the organism's ability to survive and reproduce, they die with the organism.

Depends on your definition of silence. Practical silence is subjective. If I took a microphone that could "hear" every sound in the universe to a room in which I could hear nothing and played back what I recorded, I would hear everything in the universe if I turned the volume up infinitely high. Real silence is only possible in a perfect vacuum because sound waves need a medium to travel through. If you record in a perfect vacuum, you would hear nothing no matter how high you turned the volume.

Because the definition of a "scientific theory" is completely different from an "everyday theory". I see your obligatory clapping and agree, but I have also experienced clapping in situations where it was not obligatory, e.g. in a movie theater. Pain acts as a deterrent for certain actions. For example, touching a hot stove induces pain which causes you to move your hand away because if you don't, you will kill the cells in your hand. We still *are* apes. But to answer your question, there were environmental pressures on us to use our brains more or starve out in a changing, drying climate. Foraging on two legs instead of four saves tremendous energy, meaning we had more energy for developing social behaviors and tool building. Large brains are terribly "expensive" (energy consuming), but we found the food sources to support them. Other apes live in wetter areas, so they don't need much change. There's more to it, of course.

That's a common misconception. We didn't evolve /from/ apes, it's just that we share common ancestors. From this common ancestor that is now extinct, some evolved into monkeys and the like while others evolved into humans, over an extremely long period of time.

Evolution by natural selection is not a matter of choice. Those with bad traits (like lungs that breathed inefficiently, for example) NATURALLY died out while those with good traits lived on. After a very long time, new species emerges.

I don't know, but it makes sense that if a species splits off and traveled into different areas with different climates and different predators, different mutations would help them survive and so two species form from one.

No heat source from here on out, or from the beginning of time?
Ultimately, if there was no heat source there would be no cold as everything in the universe would be at the same temperature, no heat source -> no fluctuation -> no heat/cold, just a constant.
